I'm shocked at how historically inaccurate this story is.  Confederate forces  retreated and abandoned Atlanta on Sept 1, 1864 and exploded what munitions they could not take with them which resulted in fires that burned a few buildings.  This was NOT the burning of Atlanta.  The burning of Atlanta took place on Sherman's orders on Nov 15, 1864, 45 days after the city surrendered to Union forces and was occupied by  Sherman.  Sherman publicly announced his intention to burn the city to the ground and the city father's begged him not to as it would leave much of the city's population (mostly women, children & elderly) homeless.  Their correspondence is preserved in writing and is heartbreaking to read.  Why would a military commander burn a city to the ground that had no opposing forces in it and had submitted to Union authority?  An act which would result in many unnecessary civilian deaths.  It remains one of the cruelest, unjustified acts of that war or any war.

On the eve of the Civil War a young immigrant couple had started a small glass importing business in Atlanta, they lost everything when the city burned and were forced to flee; they never returned. The couple moved north to New York City and reestablished their business importing glass, porcelains, and household goods eventually buying out their main retail customer and building it into the most famous retailer in the world. The couple were Isidor and Ida Strauss, the retailer they bought was R.H. Macy & Company but history remembers them most as the elderly couple so devoted to each other they refused to be parted in the face of disaster and were lost aboard RMS Titanic.

Read the remarkable letters that passed between Generals John Bell Hood and William T. Sherman regarding the fate of Atlanta. Sherman asked for a truce in order to remove the citizens and as much of their belongings and baggage as could be carried. (Curiously, Sherman allows these folks to keep their slaves as long as those slaves go willingly and not forcibly. So much for the "Army of the Lord" fighting for an end to slavery, but then, Sherman was a virulent racist.) He needed the Confederate Army of Tennessee's help (wagons, horses, etc.) conducting the citizens southward. In response, Hood agrees but adds:
"And now, sir, permit me to say that the unprecedented measure you propose transcends, in studied and ingenious cruelty, all acts ever before brought to my attention in the dark history of war. In the name of God and humanity I protest, believing that you will find that you are expelling from their homes and firesides the wives and children of a brave people." Post evacuation, Atlanta was burned.

I had always been taught that General Sherman and the Union Army were responsible for torching the city.

Here's what National Geographic has to say about it:

"On November 15, 1864, United States forces led by Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman burned nearly all of the captured city of Atlanta, Georgia, United States."

"More than 3,000 buildings (including businesses, hospitals, homes, and schools) were destroyed. The Atlanta Campaign aimed to cut off Atlanta’s vital supply lines that provided Confederate troops with reinforcements, ammunition, and goods such as clothes, first-aid medicines, and equipment. As Atlanta lay smoldering, Sherman and his troops began their audacious, infamous “March to the Sea,” a massive scorched-earth campaign that ended in the port city of Savannah, Georgia, on December 21."
